title: London Taxi Company opens £300m electric black cab factory in Coventry
text:
London Taxi Company opens £300m electric black cab factory in Coventry The London Taxi Company is aiming to produce 5,000 vehicles a year by 2019. Telegraph Reporters 22 March 2017 • 7:33am 
T he opening of a new car factory in Coventry is a signal of China's confidence in the UK post-Brexit, its owners have said. 
The plant at Ansty in the West Midlands will produce thousands of electric vehicles from later in the year, following a £300m investment by its Chinese owners Geely. 
The London Taxi Company is aiming to produce 5,000 vehicles a year by 2019. 
Writing for The Telegraph , Li Shufu, chairman of Zhejiang Geely Holding Group, said: "China continues to see the UK as a hub for innovation in new energy technology, for manufacturing expertise and for skills. In numbers | UK car industry 
"This plant, and the related investment, is just one symbol of my own and the wider Chinese confidence in the UK." 
P roduction of the traditional diesel-powered taxi will be run down at the firm's Coventry site over the next year. 
Unite regional officer Peter Coulson said: "This a fantastic story of a company that was on its knees in 2013. 
"Now, thanks to the commitment of Geely's top management and accompanying large-scale investment, the iconic London taxi is set for its continued renaissance. 
"Tribute should also be paid to the dedicated workforce who have worked hard and diligently to contribute to the current success. 
"This is fantastic news in terms of highly skilled jobs for our members and the future creation of employment opportunities. It will be a wonderful boost to the West Midlands economy." Post Brexit investments in UK - chart 
T he new plant was constructed in just two years. 
Last year Geely raised $400m via a “green bond” to help finance development of the electric version of the TX5 taxi. At the time it said it was first green bond issued on international markets by a Chinese automotive company. The TX5 makes extensive use of aluminium to reduce its weight and increase efficiency. 
G eely took on London Taxi Company in 2013, when it spent £11m buying the business – then called Manganese Bronze – out of administration. Manganese Bronze collapsed the previous October after a steering fault in its most recent model sent the company into crisis.
